poem:
**Echoes in Stone**

Edinburgh's cobblestones,  
silent, beneath footfall,  
whisper tides rising,  
a history we've carried—  
not solely of bright minds,  
but shadows cast long,  
roots tangled deep,  
grown through centuries,  
now surfacing—  
our shared reckoning,  
etched in streets  
where truth  
meets our stride  
each morning anew.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "This is the week Scotland was forced to confront its role in slavery, and say: ‘Yes, that was us’ | Hannah Lavery As a child growing up in Edinburgh, I was taught this was a city built on the genius of the Scottish Enlightenment. That story was sunk deep into our bones and passed between us as our treasured inheritance. It formed our sense of ourselves and our belief in Scotland’s good and worthy contribution". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
